articles.title: Your Tastebuds Help Tell You When to Stop Eating, New Research Suggests - Gizmodo
articles.description: Scientists thought signals from the gut tell us when we're full. A new study finds the tongue plays a role, too.
articles.content: Our mouths might help keep our hunger in check. A recent study found evidence in mice that our brains rely on two separate pathways to regulate our sense of fullness and satietyone originating from t… [+3935 chars]

articles.author: Science
articles.title: Seeking satiety: From signals to solutions - Science
Repeated Omicron exposures override ancestral SARS-CoV-2 immune imprinting - Nature.com
articles.description: Exposure to early variants of SARS-CoV-2 results in immune imprinting in mouse models and in humans, reducing neutralizing antibody titres against Omicron variants, which could be mitigated with multiple updated boosters.

articles.title: HIV-1 Env trimers asymmetrically engage CD4 receptors in membranes - Nature.com
articles.description: HIV-1 Env trimers bound to one, two and three CD4 molecules are observed at membrane–membrane interfaces between HIV-1 and CD4-decorated virus-like particles.

articles.author: Science X
articles.title: Lowering a form of brain cholesterol reduces Alzheimer's-like damage in mice - Medical Xpress
articles.description: In Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, cognitive decline is driven by the over-accumulation of a normal brain protein known as tau. Wherever tau builds up, nearby brain tissue starts to degenerate and die.

articles.title: Genetic Links in Cannabis Use Disorder - Neuroscience News
articles.description: Researchers analyzed over 1 million genomes, revealing insights into cannabis use disorder and its ties to psychiatric issues, other substance abuses, and lung cancer risks.
